abstract: Borough presidents of Manhattan, Bronx and Brooklyn appoint several teenagers as unpaid members of community boards under new rule that allows 16- and 17-year-olds to join advisory groups; New York City is among growing number of municipalities across country to take steps toward involving teenagers in local politics.
lead_paragraph: This is the first year that 16- and 17-year-olds can join New York City’s local advisory groups. Nineteen were appointed, and many of them began attending meetings this month.

headline.main: Age 16, and Not Too Young to Join the Community Board
headline.print_headline: Teenagers Bring New Voices to Community Boards

snippet: This is the first year that 16- and 17-year-olds can join New York City’s local advisory groups. Nineteen were appointed, and many of them began attending meetings this month.
